div.p: SCUTAGE (ſcutagium, Sax. s cildpening), was a tax or contribution raiſed by thoſe that held lands by knights ſervice, towards furniſhing the king’s army, at one, two, or three merks for every knight’s fee. Henry III. for his voyage to the Holy Land, had a tenth granted by the clergy, and ſcutage three merks of every
knight’s ſee by the laity. This was alſo levied by Henry II. Richard I. and King John. See Knight Service.
